abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Integrated Phosphate
            Project in Jordan were as follows: overall outcome of the
            project was rated satisfactory, and the performance of the
            Bank and the Borrower were also rated satisfactory. Some of
            the lessons learned from the project are: (a) with
            relatively complex project designs, implementation schedules
            must allow for finalization of technical aspects of a
            two-stage International Commodity Body (ICB) process and
            pre-qualification procedures; (b) even with complex project
            components, substantial benefits can be realized if the
            enterprise is run on an autonomous basis and along
            quasi-commercial lines, has a committed management team and
            experienced operational staff, and gets sufficient support
            from the government as the major shareholder; (c) under
            present governance, the Borrower faces substantial financing
            constraints on its investment program; (d) mining is a high
            risk business that is best suited for private investors who
            can assume such risks, and not for using scarce fiscal
            resources under uncertain conditions; (e) since the Borrower
            is one of Jordan's leading companies and is engaged in
            producing an internationally traded commodity, partial or
            full privatization of the company can and should be
            considered which could yield substantial financial and
            economic benefits; and (f) corporate management must be
            flexible enough in such cases to quickly adjust corporate
            strategy to market fluctuations.

abstracts.cdata!:
The Integrated Phosphate Project is an
            important second step in the development of the Shidiya
            phosphate deposit, which will enable Jordan to increase its
            export of phosphate rock and to increase foreign exchange
            earnings. It will also rehabilitate the fertilizer plant at
            Aqaba. The project will finance beneficiation of plant
            equipment, including a washing and flotation plant;
            phosphate ore and product handling, storage, reclaim and
            loading facilities; townsite expansion; industrial
            infrastructure, including power distribution and water
            supply; and fertilizer plant equipment. The project's
            technical assistance component will ensure effective project
            management of the fertilizer plant rehabilitation.
